relation.name: GOVERNOR
relation.description: The "governor" grammatical relation, which is the inverse of "dependent"

relation.name: DEPENDENT
relation.description: The "dependent" grammatical relation, which is the inverse of "governor"

relation.name: PREDICATE
relation.description: The "predicate" grammatical relation. The predicate of a clause is the main VP of that clause; the predicate of a subject is the predicate of the clause to which the subject belongs.

relation.name: AUX_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "auxiliary" grammatical relation. An auxiliary of a clause is a non-main verb of the clause.

relation.name: AUX_PASSIVE_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "passive auxiliary" grammatical relation. A passive auxiliary of a clause is a non-main verb of the clause which contains the passive information.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP and < /^(?:VB|AUX)/=target < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|become|becomes|became|becoming|get|got|getting|gets|gotten|remains|remained|remain)$/ < VP|ADJP or < VBN|VBD and < VP|ADJP < VBN|VBD < CC

relation.name: COPULA
relation.description: The "copula" grammatical relation. A copula is the relation between the complement of a copular verb and the copular verb.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP < /^(?:VB|AUX)/=target and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ or $++ ADJP|NP|WHNP !< VBN $++ S <: ADJP < JJ

relation.name: CONJUNCT
relation.description: The "conjunct" grammatical relation. A conjunct is the relation between two elements connected by a conjunction word. We treat conjunctions asymmetrically: The head of the relation is the first conjunct and other conjunctions depend on it via the conj relation. Note:Modified in 2010 to exclude the case of a CC/CONJP first in its phrase: it has to conjoin things.

relation.name: COORDINATION
relation.description: The "coordination" grammatical relation. A coordination is the relation between an element and a conjunction.

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^(?:S|VP|(?:WH)?NP(?:-TMP|-ADV)?|QP|ADJP|PP|ADVP|UCP|NX|SBAR|SBARQ|SINV|SQ|JJP|NML|CONJP)/ or < CC=target !< /^(?i:either|neither|both)$/ < CONJP=target !< RB and < /^(?i:not)$/ $+ RB|JJ < /^(?i:only|just|merely)$/

relation.name: PUNCTUATION
relation.description: The "punctuation" grammatical relation. This is used for any piece of punctuation in a clause, if punctuation is being retained in the typed dependencies.

relation.name: ARGUMENT
relation.description: The "argument" grammatical relation. An argument of a VP is a subject or complement of that VP; an argument of a clause is an argument of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

relation.name: SUBJECT
relation.description: The "subject" grammatical relation. The subject of a VP is the noun or clause that performs or experiences the VP; the subject of a clause is the subject of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

relation.name: NOMINAL_SUBJECT
relation.description: The "nominal subject" grammatical relation. A nominal subject is a subject which is an noun phrase.

targetpattern.pretty: Root S < NP|WHNP=target and and !< EX !< /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/ $++ VP

Root S < NP=target and < /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/ !$++ NP $++ VP
Root SQ|PRN < NP=target and !< EX $++ VP
Root SQ < NP=target and !< EX and $- /^VB|AUX/ !$++ VP
Root SQ < NP=target and !< EX and $- RB $- /^VB|AUX/ !$++ VP
Root SBARQ and < WHNP=target < SQ < VP !$-- NP
Root SINV < NP|WHNP=target or $- VP|VBZ|VBD|VBP|VB|MD|AUX $- @RB|ADVP $- VP|VBZ|VBD|VBP|VB|MD|AUX and !$- __ !$ @NP
Root S and < NP=target $+ NP|ADJP > VP

targetpattern.compile: SBAR < WHNP=target [ < (S < (VP !$-- NP) !< SBAR) | < (VP !$-- NP) !< S ]
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and < WHNP=target or < S and < VP !$-- NP !< SBAR and < VP !$-- NP !< S
Root SBAR and !< WHNP < S !< NP $++ VP > VP > S $- WHNP=target
Root SQ < NP and < EX $++ NP=target
Root S and < NP < EX <+(VP) VP < NP=target

relation.name: NOMINAL_PASSIVE_SUBJECT
relation.description: The "nominal passive subject" grammatical relation. A nominal passive subject is a subject of a passive which is an noun phrase. This pattern recognizes basic (non-coordinated) examples. The coordinated examples are currently handled by correctDependencies() in EnglishGrammaticalStructure. This seemed more accurate than any tregex expression we could come up with.

targetpattern.pretty: Root S|SQ and < /^(?:WH)?NP$/=target !< EX < VP and < /^(VB|AUX)/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|become|becomes|became|becoming|get|got|getting|gets|gotten|remains|remained|remain)$/ < VP < VBN|VBD

relation.name: CLAUSAL_SUBJECT
relation.description: The "clausal subject" grammatical relation. A clausal subject is a subject which is a clause. (subject is "what she said" in both examples)

targetpattern.pretty: Root S < SBAR|S=target and !$+ /^,$/ $++ VP !$-- NP

relation.name: CLAUSAL_PASSIVE_SUBJECT
relation.description: The "clausal passive subject" grammatical relation. A clausal passive subject is a subject of a passive verb which is a clause. (subject is "that she lied")

targetpattern.pretty: Root S < SBAR|S=target and !$+ /^,$/ $++ VP and < VP < VBN|VBD < /^(VB|AUXG?)/ < /be|was|is|are|were|been|being|'s|'re|'m|am|Been|Being|WAS|IS|get|got|getting|gets|Get|gotten|becomes|become|became|felt|feels|feel|seems|seem|seemed|remains|remained|remain/ !$-- NP

Root S < SBAR|S=target and !$+ /^,$/ $++ VP and <+(VP) VP and < VBN|VBD > VP < /^(VB|AUXG?)/ < /be|was|is|are|were|been|being|'s|'re|'m|am|Been|Being|WAS|IS|get|got|getting|gets|Get|gotten|becomes|become|became|felt|feels|feel|seems|seem|seemed|remains|remained|remain/ !$-- NP

example.text: That she lied was suspected by everyone

relation.name: COMPLEMENT
relation.description: The "complement" grammatical relation. A complement of a VP is any object (direct or indirect) of that VP, or a clause or adjectival phrase which functions like an object; a complement of a clause is an complement of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

relation.name: OBJECT
relation.description: The "object" grammatical relation. An object of a VP is any direct object or indirect object of that VP; an object of a clause is an object of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

relation.name: DIRECT_OBJECT
relation.description: The "direct object" grammatical relation. The direct object of a VP is the noun phrase which is the (accusative) object of the verb; the direct object of a clause is the direct object of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP and !< /^VB|AUXG?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ < /^(NP|WHNP)$/=target or and !< /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/ !$+ NP $+ NP-TMP $+ NP < /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/

targetpattern.compile: SBARQ < (WHNP=target !< WRB !< (/^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/)) <+(SQ|SINV|S|VP) (VP !< NP|TO !< (S < (VP < TO)) !< (/^VB|AUXG?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $++ (VP < VBN|VBD)) !<- PRT !<- (PP <: IN) $-- (NP !< /^-NONE-$/))
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBARQ and < WHNP=target and !< WRB !< /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/ <+(SQ|SINV|S|VP) VP and !< NP|TO !< S < VP < TO !< /^VB|AUXG?/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $++ VP < VBN|VBD !<-1 PRT !<-1 PP <: IN $-- NP !< /^-NONE-$/

targetpattern.compile: SBAR < (WHNP=target !< WRB) < (S < NP < (VP !< SBAR !<+(VP) (PP <- IN) !< (S < (VP < TO))))
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and < WHNP=target !< WRB < S and < NP < VP and !< SBAR !<+(VP) PP <-1 IN !< S < VP < TO
Root SBAR and !< WHNP|WHADVP < S < @NP $++ VP !$++ NP > VP > S and < NP $- WHNP=target

targetpattern.compile: SBAR !< (WHPP|WHNP|WHADVP) < (S < (@NP $+ (VP !< (/^(?:VB|AUX)/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP) !<+(VP) (/^(?:VB|AUX)/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $+ (VP < VBN|VBD)) !<+(VP) NP !< SBAR !<+(VP) (PP <- IN)))) !$-- CC $-- NP > NP=target
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and !< WHPP|WHNP|WHADVP < S < @NP $+ VP and !< /^(?:VB|AUX)/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP !<+(VP) /^(?:VB|AUX)/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $+ VP < VBN|VBD !<+(VP) NP !< SBAR !<+(VP) PP <-1 IN !$-- CC $-- NP > NP=target

targetpattern.compile: SBAR !< (WHPP|WHNP|WHADVP) < (S < (@NP $+ (ADVP $+ (VP !< (/^(?:VB|AUX)/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP) !<+(VP) (/^(?:VB|AUX)/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $+ (VP < VBN|VBD)) !<+(VP) NP !< SBAR !<+(VP) (PP <- IN))))) !$-- CC $-- NP > NP=target
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and !< WHPP|WHNP|WHADVP < S < @NP $+ ADVP $+ VP and !< /^(?:VB|AUX)/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP !<+(VP) /^(?:VB|AUX)/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $+ VP < VBN|VBD !<+(VP) NP !< SBAR !<+(VP) PP <-1 IN !$-- CC $-- NP > NP=target

relation.name: INDIRECT_OBJECT
relation.description: The "indirect object" grammatical relation. The indirect object of a VP is the noun phrase which is the (dative) object of the verb; the indirect object of a clause is the indirect object of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP < NP=target < NP and !< /\$/ $++ NP !< /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter|lot$/ !$ CC|CONJP !$ /^,$/ !$++ /^:$/

relation.name: PREPOSITIONAL_OBJECT
relation.description: The "prepositional object" grammatical relation. The object of a preposition is the head of a noun phrase following the preposition, or the adverbs "here" and "there". (The preposition in turn may be modifying a noun, verb, etc.) We here define cases of VBG quasi-prepositions like "including", "concerning", etc. as instances of pobj (unlike the Penn Treebank). (The preposition can be called a FW for pace, versus, etc. It can also be called a CC - but we don't currently handle that and would need to distinguish from conjoined PPs. Jan 2010 update: We now insist that the NP must follow the preposition. This prevents a preceding NP measure phrase being matched as a pobj. We do allow a preposition tagged RB followed by an NP pobj, as happens in the Penn Treebank for adverbial uses of PP like "up 19%")

targetpattern.pretty: Root PRT >-1 VP and !< S < VP < TO >+(SQ|SINV|S|VP) SBARQ <1 WHNP=target !< WRB $-- NP !< /^-NONE-$/
Root PP and <: IN|TO >-1 VP and !< S < VP < TO >+(SQ|SINV|S|VP) SBARQ <1 WHNP=target !< WRB $-- NP !< /^-NONE-$/
Root PP and <: IN|TO and $- NP and $-- VBZ|VBD !$++ VP >+(SQ) SBARQ <1 WHNP=target !< WRB $-- NP !< /^-NONE-$/

targetpattern.compile: (PP <- IN|TO) >+(@VP|S|SINV|SBAR) (SBAR !< (WHPP|WHNP) < (S < (NP $+ (VP !<(/^VB|AUXG?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP) !<+(VP) NP !< SBAR ))) $-- NP > NP=target)
targetpattern.pretty: Root PP and <-1 IN|TO >+(@VP|S|SINV|SBAR) SBAR and !< WHPP|WHNP < S < NP $+ VP and !< /^VB|AUXG?/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP !<+(VP) NP !< SBAR $-- NP > NP=target
Root PP and < CC < less < NP

relation.name: PREPOSITIONAL_COMPLEMENT
relation.description: The "prepositional complement" grammatical relation. This is used when the complement of a preposition is a clause or an adverbial or prepositional phrase. The prepositional complement of a preposition is the head of the sentence following the preposition, or the preposition head of the PP. It is warmer in Greece than in Italy &arr; pcomp(than, in)

targetpattern.pretty: Root @PP and !< IN|TO < SBAR=target <1 IN $+ S

example.text: We have no useful information on whether users are at risk
They heard about you missing classes.

relation.name: ATTRIBUTIVE
relation.description: The "attributive" grammatical relation. The attributive is the complement of a verb such as "to be, to seem, to appear". These mainly occur in questions. Arguably they shouldn't and we should treat the question WHNP and WHADJP as predicates (as we do for ADJP and NP complements (NP-PRD and ADJP-PRD), but we at present don't produce this.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP and !$ NP < EX < NP=target < /^VB|AUXG?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/

Root SBARQ < WHNP|WHADJP=target $+ SQ and < /^VB|AUX?/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$++ VP !< VP <-1 PP <: IN !<-1 PP <: IN

targetpattern.compile: SBARQ <, (WHNP|WHADJP=target !< WRB) <+(SQ|SINV|S|VP) (VP !< (S < (VP < TO)) < (/^VB|AUX?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $++ (VP < VBN|VBD)) !<- PRT !<- (PP <: IN) $-- (NP !< /^-NONE-$/))
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBARQ and <1 WHNP|WHADJP=target !< WRB <+(SQ|SINV|S|VP) VP and !< S < VP < TO < /^VB|AUX?/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ $++ VP < VBN|VBD !<-1 PRT !<-1 PP <: IN $-- NP !< /^-NONE-$/

Root SQ and <1 /^VB|AUX?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ < NP=target $-- NP !< EX

relation.name: CLAUSAL_COMPLEMENT
relation.description: The "clausal complement" grammatical relation. A clausal complement of a verb or adjective is a dependent clause with an internal subject which functions like an object of the verb, or adjective. Clausal complements for nouns are limited to complement clauses with a subset of nouns like "fact" or "report". We analyze them the same (parallel to the analysis of this class as "content clauses" in Huddleston and Pullum 2002). Clausal complements are usually finite (though there are occasional exceptions including remnant English subjunctives, and we also classify the complement of causative "have" (She had him arrested) in this category.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP < S=target and < VP !<1 TO|VBG|VBN !$-- NP
Root VP < SBAR=target and < S <+(S) VP <1 IN|DT < /^(that|whether)$/
Root VP < SBAR=target and < SBAR and < S <+(S) VP <1 IN|DT < /^(that|whether)$/ < CC|CONJP
Root VP < SBAR=target and < S < VP !$-- NP !<1 IN|WHADVP
Root VP < SBAR=target and < S < VP !$-- NP <1 WHADVP < WRB < /^[Hh]ow$/
Root VP and < /^VB/ < /^(?i:have|had|has|having)$/ < S=target and < @NP < VP
Root S|SINV < S|SBARQ=target and $+ /^(,|\.|'')$/ !$- /^:|CC$/ !< VP < TO|VBG|VBN
Root ADVP < SBAR=target and < IN < as|that < S < VP !< TO
Root ADJP < SBAR=target and < IN !< than < S < VP !< TO
Root S <1 SBAR=target and <1 IN < /^(?i:that|whether)$/ !$+ VP

example.text: He says that you like to swim
I am certain that he did it
I admire the fact that you are honest

relation.name: XCLAUSAL_COMPLEMENT
relation.description: An open clausal complement (xcomp) of a VP or an ADJP is a clausal complement without its own subject, whose reference is determined by an external subject. These complements are always non-finite. The name xcomp is borrowed from Lexical-Functional Grammar. (Mainly "TO-clause" are recognized, but also some VBG like "stop eating")

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP and !> VP < VB|AUX < be < S=target and !$- NN < /^order$/ < VP < TO
Root VP < S=target and !$- NN < /^order$/ < NP $+ NP|ADJP
Root VP < /^VB|AUX/ $+ VP=target and < VB < NP
Root VP and !> VP < VB|AUX < be < SBAR=target < S and !$- NN < /^order$/ < VP < TO
Root VP and > VP < S=target and !$- NN < /^order$/ <: NP
Root VP < S=target and !< NP < VP < VBG

relation.name: COMPLEMENTIZER
relation.description: The "complementizer" grammatical relation. A complementizer of a clausal complement is the word introducing it.

targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and <1 IN|DT=target < /^(?:that|whether)$/ or $-- /^VB|AUXG?/ $- NP|NN|NNS > ADJP|PP > @NP|UCP|SBAR and < CC|CONJP $-- /^VB|AUXG?/

example.text: He says that you like to swim

relation.name: MARKER
relation.description: The "marker" grammatical relation. A marker of an adverbial clausal complement is the word introducing it.

example.text: U.S. forces have been engaged in intense fighting after insurgents launched simultaneous attacks

relation.name: RELATIVE
relation.description: The "relative" grammatical relation. A relative of a relative clause is the head word of the WH-phrase introducing it. Note that this is designed to *not* match cases when there is no overt subject NP. They are instead matched by the nsubj rule. Effectively this gives us an HPSG-like relative clause analysis, where subject relatives are analyzed as regular subject structures. And "why" (WHADVP) cases are treated as advmod not as rel.

targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and <1 WHNP|WHPP|WHADJP=target > /^NP/ or !<1 /^WHNP/ < S < VP $-- /^NP/ !< /^-NONE-$/

example.text: I saw the man that you love
I saw the man whose wife you love

relation.name: REFERENT
relation.description: The "referent" grammatical relation. A referent of the Wh-word of a NP is the relative word introducing the relative clause modifying the NP.

targetpattern.pretty: Root NP and $+ SBAR <+(SBAR) WHNP|WHPP <+(@WHNP|WHPP|NP|PP) /^WDT|WP|WP\$$/=target > NP
Root NP and $+ /^(,|PP|PRN)$/ $+ SBAR < WHNP|WHPP <+(@WHNP|WHPP|NP|PP) /^WDT|WP|WP\$$/=target > NP
Root NP and $+ /^(,|PP|PRN)$/ $+ /^("|''|,)$/ $+ SBAR < WHNP|WHPP <+(@WHNP|WHPP|NP|PP) /^WDT|WP|WP\$$/=target > NP

example.text: I saw the book which you bought
I saw the book the cover of which you designed

relation.name: EXPLETIVE
relation.description: The "expletive" grammatical relation. This relation captures an existential there.

example.text: There is a statue in the corner

relation.name: ADJECTIVAL_COMPLEMENT
relation.description: The "adjectival complement" grammatical relation. An adjectival complement of a VP is an adjectival phrase which functions as the complement (like an object of the verb); an adjectival complement of a clause is the adjectival complement of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP or < ADJP=target !$-- NP < /^VB/ $+ @S=target < @ADJP and < /^JJ/ !$-- @NP|S

relation.name: MODIFIER
relation.description: The "modifier" grammatical relation. A modifier of a VP is any constituent that serves to modify the meaning of the VP (but is not an ARGUMENT of that VP); a modifier of a clause is an modifier of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

example.text: Last night, I swam in the pool
example.coding: mod(swam, in the pool), mod(swam, last night)

relation.name: ADV_CLAUSE_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "adverbial clause modifier" grammatical relation. An adverbial clause modifier of a VP is a clause modifying the verb (temporal clauses, consequences, conditional clauses, etc.).

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP < @SBAR=target or <1 IN and !< /^([Tt]hat|[Ww]hether)$/ !$+ NN < /^order$/ <: SINV <1 /^(?:VB|MD)/ and < IN < that < RB|IN < so
Root S|SQ <1 /^SBAR(?:-TMP)?$/=target and <1 IN and !< /^([Tt]hat|[Ww]hether)$/ !$+ NN < /^order$/ !$+ VP
Root S|SQ < /^SBAR(?:-TMP)?$/=target and <1 IN and !< /^([Tt]hat|[Ww]hether)$/ !$+ NN < /^order$/ !$+ @VP $+ /^,$/ $++ @NP
Root VP < /^SBAR(?:-TMP)?$/=target and <1 WHADVP|WHNP < WRB !< /^[Hh]ow$/ !< S < VP < TO
Root S|SQ < /^SBAR(?:-TMP)?$/=target and <1 WHADVP|WHNP < WRB !< /^[Hh]ow$/ !< S < VP < TO

example.text: The accident happened as the night was falling
If you know who did it, you should tell the teacher

relation.name: PURPOSE_CLAUSE_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "purpose clause modifier" grammatical relation. A purpose clause modifier of a VP is a clause headed by "(in order) to" specifying a purpose. Note: at present we only recognize ones that have "in order to" or are fronted. Otherwise we can't use our surface representations distinguish these from xcomp's. We can also recognize "to" clauses introduced by "be VBN".

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP < /^SBAR/=target and < IN < in < NN < order < S < VP < TO

example.text: He talked to the president in order to secure the account

relation.name: RELATIVE_CLAUSE_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "relative clause modifier" grammatical relation. A relative clause modifier of an NP is a relative clause modifying the NP. The link points from the head noun of the NP to the head of the relative clause, normally a verb.

targetpattern.pretty: Root NP|WHNP|NML and $++ SBAR=target <: S !<1 VP <1 TO > @NP|WHNP
Root NP|NML and $++ SBAR=target < WHADVP < WRB < /^(where|why)/ > @NP

example.text: I saw the man you love
I saw the book which you bought

relation.name: ADJECTIVAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "adjectival modifier" grammatical relation. An adjectival modifier of an NP is any adjectival phrase that serves to modify the meaning of the NP. The relation amod is also used for multiword country adjectives, despite their questionable treebank representation.

targetpattern.pretty: Root ADJP and !< CC|CONJP < JJ|NNP $ JJ|NNP=target

relation.name: NUMERIC_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "numeric modifier" grammatical relation. A numeric modifier of an NP is any number phrase that serves to modify the meaning of the NP.

relation.name: NUMBER_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "compound number modifier" grammatical relation. A compound number modifier is a part of a number phrase or currency amount.

relation.name: QUANTIFIER_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "quantifier phrase modifier" grammatical relation. A quantifier modifier is an element modifying the head of a QP constituent.

example.text: About 200 people came to the party

relation.name: NOUN_COMPOUND_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "noun compound modifier" grammatical relation. A noun compound modifier of an NP is any noun that serves to modify the head noun. Note that this has all nouns modify the rightmost a la Penn headship rules. There is no intelligent noun compound analysis.

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^(?:WH)?(?:NP|NX|NAC|NML)(?:-TMP|-ADV)?$/ and < NP|NML|NN|NNS|NNP|NNPS|FW=target and !<<- POS $+ JJ|JJR|JJS <# NN|NNS|NNP|NNPS !<<- POS
Root ADJP|ADVP < FW or $- FW=target $- IN=target < in|In

relation.name: APPOSITIONAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "appositional modifier" grammatical relation. An appositional modifier of an NP is an NP that serves to modify the meaning of the NP. It includes parenthesized examples

example.text: Sam, my brother, eats red meat

relation.name: ABBREVIATION_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "abbreviation modifier" grammatical relation. An abbreviation modifier of an NP is a parenthesized NP that serves to abbreviate the NP (or to define an abbreviation). Abbreviations are recognized either by being deemed proper nouns or by matching a regex pattern.

relation.name: PARTICIPIAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "participial modifier" grammatical relation. A participial modifier of an NP or VP (or S) is a VP[part] that serves to modify the meaning of the NP or VP.

targetpattern.pretty: Root S|SINV < S=target and < VP <1 VBG|VBN or $- /^,$/ or $- @NP $- @PP $ @NP $+ /^,$/ $+ @NP
Root VP < S=target and < VP <1 VBG|VBN $- /^,$/ or $- @NP $- @PP $ @NP

example.text: truffles picked during the spring are tasty
Bill picked Fred for the team demonstrating his incompetence

relation.name: INFINITIVAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "infinitival modifier" grammatical relation. An infinitival modifier of an NP is an S/VP that serves to modify the meaning of the NP.

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^NP(?:-[A-Z]+)?$/ < SBAR=target and < S < VP < TO $-- /^NP|NNP?S?$/

relation.name: ADVERBIAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "adverbial modifier" grammatical relation. An adverbial modifier of a word is a (non-clausal) RB or ADVP that serves to modify the meaning of the word.

targetpattern.pretty: Root ADVP|WHADVP and < RB|RBR|RBS|WRB|ADVP|WHADVP|JJ=target !< /^(?i:n[o']?t|never)$/ !< CC !< CONJP

relation.name: NEGATION_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "negation modifier" grammatical relation. The negation modifier is the relation between a negation word and the word it modifies.

relation.name: NP_ADVERBIAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "noun phrase as adverbial modifier" grammatical relation. This relation captures various places where something syntactically a noun phrase is used as an adverbial modifier in a sentence. These usages include: A measure phrase, which is the relation between the head of an ADJP/ADVP and the head of a measure-phrase modifying the ADJP/ADVP. Noun phrases giving extent inside a VP which are not objects Financial constructions involving an adverbial or PP-like NP, notably the following construction where the NP means "per share" Reflexives Certain other absolutive NP constructions. A temporal modifier (tmod) is a subclass of npadvmod which is distinguished as a separate relation.

example.text: 90% of Australians like him, the most of any country

relation.name: TEMPORAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "temporal modifier" grammatical relation. A temporal modifier of a VP or an ADJP is any constituent that serves to modify the meaning of the VP or the ADJP by specifying a time; a temporal modifier of a clause is an temporal modifier of the VP which is the predicate of that clause.

targetpattern.pretty: Root S < /^NP-TMP$/=target and $++ VP or $++ NP $-- NP

Root S < NP=target and < /^NN/ < /(?i)^Mondays?|Tuesdays?|Wednesdays?|Thursdays?|Fridays?|Saturdays?|Sundays?|years?|months?|weeks?|days?|mornings?|evenings?|nights?|January|Jan\.|February|Feb\.|March|Mar\.|April|Apr\.|May|June|July|August|Aug\.|September|Sept\.|October|Oct\.|November|Nov\.|December|Dec\.|today|yesterday|tomorrow|spring|summer|fall|autumn|winter$/ $++ NP $++ VP

targetpattern.compile: SBAR < (@WHADVP < (WRB < when)) < (S < (NP $+ (VP !< (/^VB|AUXG?/ < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP) ))) !$-- CC $-- NP > NP=target
targetpattern.pretty: Root SBAR and < @WHADVP < WRB < when < S < NP $+ VP !< /^VB|AUXG?/ and < /^(?i:am|is|are|be|being|'s|'re|'m|was|were|been|s|ai|seem|seems|seemed|seeming|appear|appears|appeared|stay|stays|stayed|remain|remains|remained|resemble|resembles|resembled|resembling|become|becomes|became|becoming)$/ !$+ VP !$-- CC $-- NP > NP=target

example.text: Last night, I swam in the pool

relation.name: MULTI_WORD_EXPRESSION
relation.description: The "multi-word expression" grammatical relation. This covers various multi-word constructions for which it would seem pointless or arbitrary to claim grammatical relations between words: as well as, rather than, instead of, but also; such as, because of, all but, in addition to ....

targetpattern.pretty: Root PP|XS and < IN|TO < as|of|at|to|in < JJ|IN|JJR|JJS|NN=target < such|because|Because|least|instead|due|Due|addition|to
Root ADVP and < RB|IN < well < IN|RB|JJS=target < as
Root ADVP and < DT < all < CC < but
Root CONJP and < RB < rather|well|instead < RB|IN=target < as|than|of
Root CONJP and < IN < in < NN|TO=target < addition|to

relation.name: DETERMINER
relation.description: The "determiner" grammatical relation.

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^NP(?:-TMP|-ADV)?$/ < DT=target and < /both|either|neither/ !$+ DT !$++ CC $++ /^N[NX]/ !$++ NP < CC

relation.name: PREDETERMINER
relation.description: The "predeterminer" grammatical relation.

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^(?:WH)?NP(?:-TMP|-ADV)?$/ and < PDT|DT=target and $+ DT $++ /^JJ/ !$+ /^NN/ !$++ CC

relation.name: PRECONJUNCT
relation.description: The "preconjunct" grammatical relation.

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^NP(?:-TMP|-ADV)?|NX$/ < CONJP=target and < RB < /^(?i:not)$/ < RB|JJ < /^(?i:only|merely|just)$/ $++ CC|CONJP
Root S|VP|ADJP|PP|ADVP|UCP|NX|SBAR < CONJP=target and < RB < /^(?i:not)$/ < RB|JJ < /^(?i:only|merely|just)$/ $++ CC|CONJP

example.text: Both the boys and the girls are here

relation.name: POSSESSION_MODIFIER
relation.description:
The "possession" grammatical relation between the possessum and the possessor. Examples:
"their offices" → poss(offices, their)
"Bill 's clothes" → poss(clothes, Bill)

targetpattern.pretty: Root /^(?:WH)?NP(?:-TMP|-ADV)?$/ or and < /^(?:WH)?NP$/=target < POS !< CC|CONJP $++ /^(?:WH)?NP$/ < /^(?:WH)?NP$/=target and < CC|CONJP $++ /^(?:WH)?NP$/ < /^(?:WH)?NP$/ < POS

relation.name: POSSESSIVE_MODIFIER
relation.description:
The "possessive" grammatical relation. This is the relation given to 's (or ' with plurals). Example:
"John's book" → possessive(John, 's)

relation.name: PREPOSITIONAL_MODIFIER
relation.description: The "prepositional modifier" grammatical relation. A prepositional modifier of a verb, adjective, or noun is any prepositional phrase that serves to modify the meaning of the verb, adjective, or noun. We also generate prep modifiers of PPs to account for treebank (PP PP PP) constructions (from 1984 through 2002).

example.text: I saw a cat in a hat
I saw a cat with a telescope

relation.name: PHRASAL_VERB_PARTICLE
relation.description: The "phrasal verb particle" grammatical relation. The "phrasal verb particle" relation identifies phrasal verb.

relation.name: PARATAXIS
relation.description: The "parataxis" grammatical relation. Relation between the main verb of a sentence and other sentential elements, such as a sentential parenthetical, a sentence after a ":" or a ";" etc.

targetpattern.pretty: Root VP $ PRN=target or < S|SBAR and < VP < @NP

example.text: The guy, John said, left early in the morning.

relation.name: SEMANTIC_DEPENDENT
relation.description: The "semantic dependent" grammatical relation has been introduced as a supertype for the controlling subject relation.

relation.name: CONTROLLING_SUBJECT
relation.description: The "controlling subject" grammatical relation. A controlling subject is the relation between the head of an xcomp and the external subject of that clause.

targetpattern.compile: VP < TO > (S !$- NP !< NP !>> (VP < (VB|AUX < be)) >+(VP) (VP $-- NP=target))
targetpattern.pretty: Root VP and < TO > S and !$- NP !< NP !>> VP < VB|AUX < be >+(VP) VP $-- NP=target

relation.name: AGENT
relation.description: The "agent" grammatical relation. The agent of a passive VP is the complement introduced by "by" and doing the action.

example.text: The man has been killed by the police
